Personal opinion: this doesn't make sense. I could think of a lot of disaster scenario's waiting to happen.
That means that a variable could or not be available in the order that different DAG's are run.
You should treat Variables as constants. Defined outside of the DAG's.
I agree with @alexvanboxel a "get" should never do a "set", that is unexpected behavior. Catch the exception and then create the value if needed.
Welcome! But could you make sure to use the alphabetical order?

I'm not sure I think disaster is appropriate, nor do I think unexpected behavior is accurate, as you have to set a flag. Also, catching exceptions isn't a great way to handle constants either.
We leverage variables heavily, and find that we use the default var to handle exceptions that occur when migrating from qa to prod. Those then become opaque configuration settings.

Ben
Get Outlook for iOS

On Tue, Aug 30, 2016 at 7:12 AM -0700, "bolkedebruin" notifications@github.com wrote:

I agree with @alexvanboxel a "get" should never do a "set", that is unexpected behavior. Catch the exception and then create the value if needed.

—
You are receiving this because you authored the thread.
Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub, or mute the thread.
LGTM

@r39132 I don't believe this undoes the fix in https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/pull/1716. It continues to call `dag.reached_max_runs` but allows existing DAGs to be processed.

It may not solve the cross-dag vs in-dag run ordering problem, and I don't know that it will prevent a backfill from exceeding the number of concurrent DAG runs. Still, it's progress from stalling ALL processing for a DAG once its max_runs is reached.

Part of the problem is that DAGs are created as `RUNNING`. 

The `create_dagrun` function (not to be confused with `create_dag_run`) does NOT gate on whether `max_runs` has been reached. The dagrun_operator, backfill, trigger_dag, and the scheduler all call `create_dagrun` directly and expect it to succeed.

Is it possible to add a `QUEUED` state to DagRun like there exists for TASKS? Just a thought.

I think we should have a period where we are free to make breaking changes to the api and not bump the api version. Personally I would do this by not versioning the api (until we decide to stabalize the api), but we could also use `/api/v0`  to indicate that.

+1 for using url variables rather than query params. I think a fully RESTful api would be

```
GET /dags/<dag_id>/tasks/<task_id>
```
Welcome!
Welcome to the Apache Airflow community!

Why not use /experimental/ for fluent endpoints? 

Btw I'll whip up something quickly that can work as a basis (wiki). Just a light set of conventions @saguziel. Might require one change in your code that instead of just returning "{'error': 'xx'} it should return a HTTP error code.

I really quickly created https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/AIRFLOW/API+Conventions . @saguziel I tried to keep them as light weight as possible. For now I would skip the authentication and content negotiation part. We should manage those by decorators. 

I agree with @zodiac that the endpoint should look like `/dags/<dag_id>/tasks/<task_id>` or (as almost everything will end up at /dags) `/tasks/<task_id>`. Full endpoint `/api/experimental/dags/my_dag/tasks/my_task`.

Next to that if you return, as mentioned, a HTTP error code when needed and a nice JSON error it should be fine and we would have made a great stride ;-).

> Why not use /experimental/ for fluent endpoints?

Sure, but there's precedent for using version 0 for "fluent endpoints" in semvar (http://semver.org/#spec-item-4)

> `/tasks/<task_id>`

I don't think this is possible , task ids do not need to be unique across all DAGs right?
@zodiac good point on both. I'm fine with /v0 although I find /experimental more clear.
I'm fine with both as well. +1 on HTTP error codes

Hey @jlowin , I've just started the smoke tests for GCS, and I will prioritise a test for this feature (test it with and without the commit. I'll keep you posted. I also am waiting for approval for the cloud docs, so we could document the breaking change.

smoke tests: https://github.com/alexvanboxel/airflow-gcp-examples
docs: https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/pull/1773
@zodiac Can you please have a look at https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/AIRFLOW-486 ? This change made the webserver not detach from the console anymore when using "-D". Thanks!
@bolkedebruin I think it's fixed now
Awesome
@alexvanboxel docs are done :)

LGTM, tests could be with self signed certificates. 

@caseyching could you please update the documentation and create a proper commit message (defining what not how, usage should be in the docs). Then I will merge.

@bolkedebruin thanks, @jlowin have a look in the "brand new" integration section in the docs. I would add a section in the beginning of the GCP section with braking changes. Later on I will add some of the other changes (but I have to go over all the GCP related commits). It would be great if @criccomini would have a look as well though.

Make sure to document breaking changes in UPDATING.md and provide a path how to upgrade.

Ok I executed this DAG for integration tests. This exhbibits the issue with slow scheduling when `min_file_process_interval = 180`. On LocalExecutor:

```
from datetime import timedelta, datetime
from airflow.models import DAG, Pool
from airflow.operators import BashOperator, SubDagOperator, DummyOperator
from airflow.executors import SequentialExecutor
import airflow


# -----------------------------------------------------------------\
# DEFINE THE POOLS
# -----------------------------------------------------------------/
session = airflow.settings.Session()
for p in ['test_pool_1', 'test_pool_2', 'test_pool_3']:
    pool = (
        session.query(Pool)
        .filter(Pool.pool == p)
        .first())
    if not pool:
        session.add(Pool(pool=p, slots=8))
        session.commit()


# -----------------------------------------------------------------\
# DEFINE THE DAG
# -----------------------------------------------------------------/

# Define the Dag Name. This must be unique.
dag_name = 'hanging_subdags_n16_sqe'

# Default args are passed to each task
default_args = {
    'owner': 'Airflow',
    'depends_on_past': False,
    'start_date': datetime(2016, 04, 10),
    'retries': 0,
    'retry_interval': timedelta(minutes=5),
    'email': ['your@email.com'],
    'email_on_failure': True,
    'email_on_retry': True,
    'wait_for_downstream': False,
}

# Create the dag object
dag = DAG(dag_name,
          default_args=default_args,
          schedule_interval='0 0 * * *'
          )

# -----------------------------------------------------------------\
# DEFINE THE TASKS
# -----------------------------------------------------------------/


def get_subdag(dag, sd_id, pool=None):
    subdag = DAG(
        dag_id='{parent_dag}.{sd_id}'.format(
            parent_dag=dag.dag_id,
            sd_id=sd_id),
        params=dag.params,
        default_args=dag.default_args,
        template_searchpath=dag.template_searchpath,
        user_defined_macros=dag.user_defined_macros,
    )

    t1 = BashOperator(
        task_id='{sd_id}_step_1'.format(
            sd_id=sd_id
        ),
        bash_command='echo "hello" && sleep 1',
        dag=subdag,
        pool=pool
    )

    t2 = BashOperator(
        task_id='{sd_id}_step_two'.format(
            sd_id=sd_id
        ),
        bash_command='echo "hello" && sleep 2',
        dag=subdag,
        pool=pool
    )

    t2.set_upstream(t1)

    sdo = SubDagOperator(
        task_id=sd_id,
        subdag=subdag,
        retries=0,
        retry_delay=timedelta(seconds=5),
        dag=dag,
        depends_on_past=False,
        executor=SequentialExecutor()
    )

    return sdo

start_task = DummyOperator(
    task_id='start',
    dag=dag
)

for n in range(1, 17):
    sd_i = get_subdag(dag=dag, sd_id='level_1_{n}'.format(n=n), pool='test_pool_1')
    sd_ii = get_subdag(dag=dag, sd_id='level_2_{n}'.format(n=n), pool='test_pool_2')
    sd_iii = get_subdag(dag=dag, sd_id='level_3_{n}'.format(n=n), pool='test_pool_3')

    sd_i.set_upstream(start_task)
    sd_ii.set_upstream(sd_i)
    sd_iii.set_upstream(sd_ii)
```

I turned on the DAG at 17:24

I haven't tested it yet but I like the idea. Because I was thinking about external triggers (iso sensors waiting for existence of stuff). I could then integrate with some other GCP stuff by having another container running and translating arbitrary web-hooks into triggers.
It's on the list of things to add to the GCP integration tests, I'll +1 as soon as I have a test for this.

@alexvanboxel Thanks. Im looking for feed back on the approach. Im not sure how to remove the code redundancy between auth for the api and the login page (and if we want to at all). Also there was some earlier deliberation on what kind of protocol should be exposed for the internal API (service to service), ie. avro or protobuf.

This change results into reported failed task (incl dagrun) while task itself succeeded: see https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/AIRFLOW-492

@normster @r39132 @plypaul
Also please have a look at https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/AIRFLOW-493 (something with the UI seems not to be right)

@dud225 just a warning that I will be closing this PR unless there is movement on this.

> Powered by [Codecov](https://codecov.io?src=pr). Last update [247955d...476e247](https://codecov.io/gh/apache/incubator-airflow/compare/247955d422a1ee32bfe8b5906c07017cd3443342...476e247a1cea1d15753cb9dfaafdd247f9b90265?src=pr)

If there was a bug introduced in the core airflow code then it should be caught by other metrics (e.g. total number of running tasks). If there is a bug in an operator it should be isolated from the core airflow code and not affect the logic in the top-level call (task_instance.run()). Because there are other states like queued it makes successes/total_runs a bit more misleading (e.g. 1 success and 100 queued tasks would result in a 1% success rate).

I Confirmed a fix for the "not processing part" by moving self._ process_task_instances to the beginning of the function to have it always executed.
